name: Lavi
comment: Weir directs it well and Robin Williams is warm in a way that feels effortless, but the story never really trusts itself. every emotional beat gets underlined twice, the dark turn arrives like it was scheduled, and by the end the manipulation is working so hard you can almost hear the gears turning. it gets you anyway though, which says something, even if you are not sure what. sweet, well made, and a little too pleased with itself.

name: Louis Cottard
comment: Few films manage to stir the soul, ignite the mind, and linger in the heart long after the credits roll. Dead Poets Society, directed by Peter Weir, is one of those rare cinematic treasures, a breathtaking celebration of individuality, courage, and the transformative power of art. From its very first moments inside the austere halls of Welton Academy, the film establishes a world bound by tradition and expectation. Into this rigid environment steps the unforgettable John Keating, portrayed with magneticâ€¦

comment: Dead Poets Society didnâ€™t just move me â€” it changed the way I look at life. A film that feels less like cinema and more like a conversation with your own conscience, reminding you that success without passion is just survival. Its emotional honesty hits hard. Expectations, fear, and the quiet struggle to own your dreams feel painfully real. It doesnâ€™t glorify rebellion.... it shows the price of it. Heartfelt, realistic, and deeply perspective-changing. Some films entertain you. This one asks who you are when no one else is watching I was good I was really good

name: GuÃ©nolÃ© Castellan
comment: This film is undoubtedly one of my favorite movies with Robin Williams. The character of Professor Keating, with his unconventional methods, who makes his wealthy students read Walt Whitman's poetry and encourages them to seize the moment, really appealed to me. Additionally, the idea of gathering with friends to read poetry, whether it's oneâ€™s own or someone else's, is something I truly appreciate. Neil's suicide is brilliantly staged, although absolutely terrible, and the final scene where students from Mr. Keating'sâ€¦

That doesnâ€™t change the fact that the underlying message remains the same: Find something to LOVE, something that encapsulates who YOU are, and chase it. â€œWhile fields like medicine, law, and engineering are necessary to sustain life, poetry, beauty, romance, and love are the passions that make life worth livingâ€. name: Matt
comment: Dead Poets Society deserves a high (but not perfect) rating because it tells an inspiring story about individuality, self-expression, and the impact a teacher can have on his students. Robin Williams delivers a heartfelt performance that brings warmth and depth to the character of Mr. Keating. However, while its message is powerful and emotional, some parts of the plot feel predictable, which keeps it from earning an even higher score. Also, the beginning was in slow and not very enjoyable, but the ending was powerful which is why I rated it higher.
